Somebody: "Wow you're such a great artist"
Me: "oh wow thank you"
Somebody: "you should really go to school for art-"
My thoughts: "IVE HEARD THIS SHIT SO MANY TIMES WHY DO PEOPLE THINK GOING TO SCHOOL FOR ART IS A GOOD IDEA ITS FUCKING IDIOTIC HOLY SHIT THIS MAKES ME SO ANGRY IF IVE GOTTEN THIS FAR WITHOUT SCHOOL WHY THE FUCK DO YOU THINK SCHOOL IS A GOOD IDEA FUCK YOU" 
Me: oh I don't want to go to school for art 
*person looks at me in confusion and disgust*

Dude this has happened to me so many times and it makes me extremely angry that people think one has to go to school for art to be a good artist. In fact I'd like to argue that it diminishes creativity and tortures the soul. At least, that's what school In general has done to me. Sorry for the vent. I'm normally not this crazy (I think) but it's one of the few things in this world that really gets to me- that people think school is such a requirement- workin�g for so�meone else just to get a good grade. It's fucking retarded.
try saying 'i prefer to make art outside of school - it's more fun, and i think there's more possibilities, less restrictions, which in turn makes the art stronger.'

one good trick is to press record (with your clip synced up) and watch it and just sort of play it, after. with the right timing. so just as soon as you see the action, look away from the screen and imagine what you just saw in your head and play it synced to that, so it will be timed right, but just a bit delayed. then just go in and move it. if it's not quite right, just do it again. or if it's midi then just nudge notes to fit. fuck it, nowadays you can nudge audio notes too anyways

You say to get better at the piano one should spend more time with it, but I'm really interested in playing chords, and naming them, is there any strategy you use when remembering how to name them?

i've just been familiar with them for so long i don't have a strategy. but i will teach you one to get you started, forgive me if you already know this one, and if you do i will tell you the next one. but the chord is called C major, or just "C" for short. and it is when you play the notes C, E, and G, at the same time, somewhere in the middle range of the keyboard (it doesn't count if you play all 3 notes in the bass range, that is just called mud. if there are any notes in the bass range it should be just 1 and it should be the C note.)  so again this is called C major, or "C" for short. if middle C is on the bottom, that's fine. if middle C is in the middle, with G under it and E above it, that is fine (there might also be C in the bass range as well). it might be middle C on top, with G and E right under it (that is probably about as low as you might go for the C chord). it could be higher, with E330(hz) then G and C above it. all these combinations are still called C, or C major. (C as a chord automatically means C major.) I hope that is enough to get you started, forgive me if you already knew all that. if you want to know more i will tell you

How can I remember how many days are in each month?
knuckles
I know there's that one poem'30 days hath...' .. but I can never remember the poem so that doesn't help.
yea that's because most of the months rhyme

I know Feb is 28 (or 29), I know Oct is 31 because of halloween, and I know July is 31 because of a friend's b-day.. but other than that, no idea which ones have 30 or 31 without looking at a calendar.

use the knuckles method. hold out your hands, palm down. make fists. look at the top of your knuckles. look at the knuckles and the spaces in between the knuckles. start counting the months from the left, with a month for each knuckle and space. the knuckles represent long months (31) and the spaces represent short months (30 or less). you will see they alternate until you reach the last knuckle (july), then you have to jump to your other hand and that's another knuckle (august) and keep going from there until you run out of months (december)
